verses.verse: (1 David complained because he was brought into such extremities that he was past all hope, but after he had rehearsed the sorrows and griefs, wherewith he was vexed.10 He recovereth himself from the bottomless pit of tentations, and groweth in hope. And here under his own person he setteth forth the figure of Christ, whom he did foresee by the spirit of prophecy, that he should marvelously, and strangely be rejected, and abased, before his Father should raise and exalt him again. My (Here appeareth that horrible conflict, which he sustained between faith and desperation.) God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me, and art so far from mine health, and from the words of my (Being tormented with extreme anguish.) roaring?
O my God, I cry by day, but thou hearest not: and by night, but (Or, I cease not.) have no audience.

But thou art holy, and dost inhabit the (He meaneth the place of praising, even the Tabernacle: or else it is so called, because he gave the people continually occasion to praise him.) praises of Israel.
Our fathers trusted in thee: they trusted, and thou didst deliver them.
They called upon thee, and were delivered: they trusted in thee, and were not confounded.

But I am a (And seeming most miserable of all creatures, which was meant of Christ. And herein appeareth the unspeakable love of God toward man, that he would thus abase his Son for our sakes.) worm, and not a man: a shame of men, and the contempt of the people.
All they that see me, have me in derision: they make a mow and nod the head, saying,
He trusted in the Lord, let him deliver him: let him save him, seeing he loveth him. (Hebrew, rolled upon God.) (Cross references: : Matt. 27:43)
But thou didst draw me out of the (Even from my birth thou hast given me occasion to trust in thee.) womb: thou gavest me hope, even at my mother’s breasts.
I was cast upon thee, even from the (For except God’s providence preserve the infants, they should perish a thousand times in the mother’s womb.) womb: thou art my God from my mother’s belly.
Be not far from me, because trouble is near: for there is none to help me.
Many young bulls have compassed me: mighty (He meaneth, that his enemies were so fat, proud, and cruel, that they were rather beasts than men.) bulls of Bashan have closed me about.
They gape upon me with their mouths, as a ramping and roaring lion.

I am like (Before he spake of the cruelty of his enemies, and now he declareth the inward griefs of the mind, so that Christ was tormented both in soul and body.) water poured out, and all my bones are out of joint: mine heart is like wax: it is molten in the midst of my bowels.
My strength is dried up like a potsherd, and my tongue cleaveth to my jaws, and thou (Thou had suffered me to be without all hope of life.) hast brought me into the dust of death.

For dogs have compassed me, and the assembly of the wicked have enclosed me: they (Thus David complaineth as though he were nailed by his enemies both hands and feet: but this was accomplished in Christ.) pierced mine hands and my feet.
I may tell all my bones, yet they behold, and look upon me.
They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.
But be not thou far off, O Lord, my strength: hasten to help me.
Deliver my soul from the sword: my (My life that is solitary, left alone and forsaken of all, Ps. 35:17 and 25:16.) desolate soul from the power of the dog.

(Christ is delivered with a more mighty deliverance by overcoming death, than if he had not tasted death at all.) Save me from the lion’s mouth, and answer me in saving me from the horns of the unicorns.
(Heb. 2:12) I will declare thy Name unto my brethren: in the midst of the Congregation will I praise thee, saying,
(He promiseth to exhort the Church that they by his example might praise the Lord.) Praise the Lord, ye that fear him: magnify ye him, all the seed of Jacob, and fear ye him all the seed of Israel.

For he hath not despised nor abhorred the affliction of the (The poor afflicted are comforted by this example of David, or Christ.) poor: neither hath he hid his face from him, but when he called unto him, he heard.

My praise shall be of thee in the great Congregation: my (Which were sacrifices of thanksgiving, which they offered by God’s commandment, when they were delivered out of any great danger.) vows will I perform before them that fear him.
(He doth allude still to the sacrifice.) The poor shall eat and be satisfied: they that seek after the Lord, shall praise him: your heart shall live forever.
All the ends of the world shall remember themselves and turn to the Lord, and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before thee.
For the kingdom is the Lord’s, and he ruleth among the nations.

All they that be fat (Though the poor be first named, as verse 26, yet the wealthy are not separated from the grace of Christ’s kingdom.) in the earth shall eat and worship: all they that go down into the dust, shall bow before him, (In whom there is no hope that he shall recover life: so neither poor nor rich, quick nor dead shall be rejected from his kingdom.) even he that cannot quicken his own soul.
(Meaning, the prosperity, which the Lord keepeth as a seed to the Church to continue his praise among men.) Their seed shall serve him: it shall be counted unto the Lord for a generation.
They shall come and shall declare his righteousness unto a people that shall be born, because he hath (That is, God hath fulfilled his promise.) done it.
